quoteFirst: The room which they occupied, while in the hotel, opened into my room; but it was now empty, and the proprietors had promised to put no one into it, unless obliged by stress of business; for it had been very convenient, for changing the air in my room. I awoke from sleep

quoteFirst: Rhamadan, the Mahommedan Lent, was announced on the 22nd June. The strictest fast was immediately commenced, lasting from before day,
quoteLast: , till sunset, seven p.m. In order to support their assumed character as Moslem; they were now obliged, during the sixteen hours, to eat only by stealth, their friend Mukni having surrounded them with spies. Mr. Ritchie only, being confined to his bed by illness, was privileged to take food or drink.

quoteFirst: Lincoln's election. The position was very laborious and exacting. It was the period of secession. Through the live-long night, till
quoteLast: , I sat at my desk editing the exciting news. The reporters usually left the room about eleven, and from that time to the hour of going to press, I was alone,--save the company of two mice that became so friendly that they would sit on my desk, and make a supper of crackers and cheese, which I doled out to them.

quoteFirst: J. Pennock Sleightholme, L.R.C.P., Lond.,[28] reports the following case: “A young man of sound constitution and good health, who had never before taken morphia hypodermically, partly as an experiment and partly with the hope of relieving some slight restlessness, injected himself, at
quoteLast: , with one-sixth of a grain of morphia. Immediately after the injection he fell down on the floor in a state of syncope, and had slight convulsive movements on one side of the body; consciousness did not entirely leave him, and after lying still for about ten minutes he was sufficiently recovered to be able to go to the next room and help himself to a couple of glasses of sherry.

quoteFirst: To these magnates, railway directors, it seemed but a little matter whether a volunteer regiment or company marched a few additional miles out and home to join a train which could, but would not, pull up at a nearer station. Then the feeding arrangements were decidedly precarious; and as men leaving home
quoteLast: , and not returning until about the same hour next day, all wearing tight uniforms with little room to stow away provisions, would be hungry, it was necessary to ensure a supply of food. Contractors in London had agreed to meet the want, but something at the last moment occurred to upset the arrangement, and on the day previous to starting this battalion found itself unprovided for.
title: The history of the 1st Batt. Wilts Volunteers, from 1861 to 1885
author: Gibney, R. D. (Robert Dwarris), 1826-1906
